case_vignette:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago she was seen for adjustment of her antihypertensive regimen and prescribed lisinopril because of persistently high blood pressure readings. A complete blood count and renal function checked at her last visit were within the normal limits. On questioning, she has had fatigue and frequent headaches over the last month. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, polycystic ovarian disease, and hyperlipidemia. Her mother has hyperthyroidism and hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide at maximum doses, lisinopril, metformin, glimepiride, and atorvastatin. She has never smoked and drinks 1–2 glasses of wine with dinner every night. She is 167 cm (5 ft 5 inches) and weighs 81.6 kg (180 lbs); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mm Hg in both arms, heart rate is 90/min, and respirations are 12/min. Examination shows an obese patient and no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7,800/mm3
Serum
Na+ 139 mEq/L
K+ 3.4 mEq/L
Cl- 100 mEq/L
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
Urea nitrogen 29 mg/dL
TSH 3 μU/mL
Urine
Blood negative
Protein negative
Glucose 1+
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I've been feeling tired and getting headaches frequently over the last month.
Have you noticed any chest pain or shortness of breath along with these symptoms?
No, I haven't experienced chest pain or shortness of breath.
Have you had any history of high blood pressure or heart disease?
Yes, I have high blood pressure, and I'm currently on medications for it.
Have you had any family history of heart disease or stroke?
My mother has issues with her thyroid and high blood pressure, but there's no mention of heart disease or stroke.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or diet?
There have been no changes in my weight or diet mentioned recently.
Have you had any recent stressful events or changes in your lifestyle?
No recent stressful events or changes in my lifestyle have been mentioned.
Have you had any recent travel history?
There's no mention of recent travel history.
Have you had any recent exposure to infections or illnesses?
I haven't had any recent exposure to infections or illnesses.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns?
No, there have been no recent changes in my sleep patterns mentioned.
Have you had any recent changes in your exercise routine?
No changes in my exercise routine have been mentioned.
Have you had any recent changes in your work schedule?
There's been no mention of changes in my work schedule.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication regimen?
Yes, two weeks ago my blood pressure medicine was adjusted and lisinopril was added.
Final Diagnosis: Hypertension with medication adjustment.

There have been no recent changes in weight, diet, stressful events, lifestyle, travel history, exposure to infections, or recent changes in sleep patterns and exercise routine.
